TVST 100.courseDesc: This course covers recent trends in television, whether on streaming services, premium channels, cable, or on network channels. The focus will be on television shows that have notable narrative and artistic characteristics early on, possibly foretelling their emergence as culturally significant later on.
TVST 100.courseDepartment: Antoinette Westphal College of Media Arts & Design

TVST 105.courseDesc: This course explores the history of television as art and communication. Topics include: the origins and development of television programming, the regulatory environment and the history of the business of television. Television programs, both fictional and non-fictional, will be viewed from the fifties through the present time.
TVST 105.courseDepartment: Antoinette Westphal College of Media Arts & Design

TVST 260.courseDesc: This course explores the history of television as art and communication. Topics include: the origins and development of television programming, the regulartory environment and the history of the business of television. Television programs, both fictional and non-fictional, will be viewed from the fifties through the present time.
TVST 260.courseDepartment: Antoinette Westphal College of Media Arts & Design

TVST 261.courseDesc: This course presents a history of broadcast introduction in the United States. It includes an introduction to the origins, portocals, and principles of journalism on television. It also acquaints students with the prominent trends, programs, and reporting styles throught the decades leading to present-day norms and motivations.
TVST 261.courseDepartment: Antoinette Westphal College of Media Arts & Design

TVST 361.courseDesc: This course explores the history of television comedy and examines its role as both programming staple and artistic form. By examining how sitcoms reflect our society and its most important social issues, the course seeks to enable students to gauge where both culture and the sitcom are headed.
TVST 361.courseDepartment: Antoinette Westphal College of Media Arts & Design

TVST 362.courseDesc: Students will view and analyze prime-time, hour-long, dramatic TV shows, starting with television's golden age of the fifties and moving to television's "second golden age" starting in the eighties. Students will examine the relationship of the series to other programs, contemporary culture, and television history.
TVST 362.courseDepartment: Antoinette Westphal College of Media Arts & Design

TVST 363.courseDesc: Students will view a progression of science fiction television shows from the fifties to the present time. Students will examine how each show uses an imagined world as a vehicle for exploring facets of our own world. The concepts and the production values will be discussed for each show.
TVST 363.courseDepartment: Antoinette Westphal College of Media Arts & Design

TVST 364.courseDesc: This course looks at acclaimed television programs from the fifties to the present, which present the experience of teenagers as central to the overall show. Students will discuss the content and form of each show, in terms of the directing, the cinematography, the editing, the production design, the sound track, as well as the acting.
TVST 364.courseDepartment: Antoinette Westphal College of Media Arts & Design

TVST 368.courseDesc: We will examine television shows from the 1950's to the present that include vampires, werewolves, witches, ghosts, demons, monsters, and other beings with unusual abilities that arise from myths, legends, fairytales, and folktales (and not from scientific fact.) We will explore a variety of supernatural themes in television drama, including those that reflect our fears of the unknown and our desires to be more than we are. We will also discuss what goes into creating a high-caliber supernatural drama television show, looking at both the content and the form. We will discuss the writing, the directing, the production design, the camerawork, the sound, the editing, and the special effects.
TVST 368.courseDepartment: Antoinette Westphal College of Media Arts & Design

TVST I199.courseDesc: Self-directed within the area of study requiring intermittent consultation with a designated instructor.
TVST I199.courseDepartment: Antoinette Westphal College of Media Arts & Design
TVST I199.repeatStatus: Can be repeated multiple times for credit
